Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2008 04:14AM Katie2u wrote: http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT00502684?term=blockers&rank=14 This Is Me:     If you find out that you have extensive IDC you may want to request that you have chemotherapy before your surgery.  This will help to kill off or shrink the tumor before they do any invasive procedure.   If they are going to do a biopsy, please be sure that you have surgery within a few days afterwards.  Do not let them talk you into waiting.......unless you decide to do the Chemo first which is what some of the top hospitals are doing now.  I also found an article today which was interesting and I wish I had known about this 3 months ago before I had surgery.  It is at the top of this post because I tried three times to post it at the bottom and kept losing my post.    Good luck!
Posts.Title: Mam, US result and Rant about waiting thisisme Beesie

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2008 06:39PM Katie2u wrote: I am so sorry for all of you that are dealing with brain mets.   An acquaintance of mine has an uncle who had extensive liver mets.  They gave him 3 months to live and that was 3 years ago and he is doing well.  He started Cecium therapy.... along with Wobenzyme supplements, Vitamin C, Vitamin D3 and a strict diet.  I think many frown on this but it is worth checking into.  From what I understand Potassium levels can go low so you have to take high potassium foods with this.  You may be able to find a holistic practitioner to monitor you.    I know that radiation is supposed to control this well so keep positive.  You are in my prayers.
Posts.Title: MOM NOW HAS BRAIN METS! cneal318 TripleNeg

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2008 05:40PM Katie2u wrote: HI Crystal:      Check out Boswellia on this web site... seems like they have had success in those with brain mets.   http://www.pinestreetfoundation.org/avenues/avenues1920/stritter1920.html.  The entire site has loads of great information.  Katie
Posts.Title: MOM NOW HAS BRAIN METS! cneal318 TripleNeg

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2008 06:28AM Katie2u wrote: HI DaisyHope:      Do not be hard on yourself.  Do your job to the best of your ability and think less of what others are thinking of your performance.  You cannot read their mind and it isn't important.  You are dealing with alot on your plate right now and they know you have been a good worker.  Be kind to yourself.  Take one step at a time.  It is very overwhelming.  You will get through this hurdle.  I know that family mean well but I have found that they can only take so much of what is going on.  They aren't walking in your shoes.  I'm learning to say a little less now whereas before I would say everything I was feeling.  I am thinking of you and know that good thoughts are coming your way.   God Bless You. Katie2u

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2008 09:34AM - edited Sep 12, 2008 09:37AM by Katie2u Hello everyone:    Thanks for sharing your stories.  I had a bilateral mastectomy in July, 2008.  My surgeon was pushing me toward reconstruction stating that woman who have  reconstruction "fair better psychologically."  Of course he is 30 something and I am 53.  I think other people (such as the nurse and doctor and other medical personnel that you have to undress for) are a little taken back by the appearance of no breasts.  Now I tell them in advance of a medical procedure... "oh by the way, I have no breasts due to breast cancer and I didn't want to startle you"  hehe    I have no regrets about not having reconstruction.  I enjoyed the temporary soft inserts that I received at the hospital and just picked up my Amoena prosthesis a couple of days ago along with some mastectomy bras.... (ps.  in case you weren't aware, insurances have to cover at least the first set of prosthesis and 6 bras from what I understand.)   I just bought a fantastic looking swimsuit and with the new prosthesis you would never know it wasn't the real deal.  :)    Good luck to everyone!!
Posts.Title: reconstruction or not ????? vivianu spar2

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2008 01:52PM Katie2u wrote: HI everyone:   When I went to pick up my prosthesis and bras the other week the lady who worked there told me that the failure rate for expanders and saline or silicone implants are fairly high.  The body can reject what isn't natural for it and they have to be removed.  I'm glad that I chose not to reconstruct.  The forms are great and look natural.  Good luck!   Katie
Posts.Title: reconstruction or not ????? vivianu spar2
